Environmental allergens are mostly proteins derived from plants, animals, and fungi that can trigger chemical and biological reaction cascades in the immune system leading to allergic sensitization and formation of IgE antibodies ( section S1).
8, 84, 103, 105− 109 Prominent examples are major allergens of birch pollen (Bet v 1), timothy grass pollen (Phl p 1), ragweed ( Ambrosia, Amb a 1), molds ( Alternaria alternata, Alt a 1, Cladosporium herbarum, Cla h 1, Aspergillus fumigatus, Asp f 1), and dust mites (Der p 1).
4, 139, 140 Besides allergens, also adjuvants and their interaction with the immune system play a critical role in the development of allergies. Here, we use the term adjuvant generically for substances that are promoting pro-allergic immune responses. Adjuvants can trigger the immune system by inducing tissue damage and subsequent enhanced uptake of allergens, by inducing oxidative stress and activation of immune cells, by coexposure with the allergen favoring Th2 responses, or by modification of allergens enhancing their allergic potential.
